content.body: Tabatkins: your hypothetical <sandbox> would get similar objections from me as <template>
hsivonen: how do you feel about the hypothetical <template srcdoc="">?

Hixie: I think it would be mostly inconvenient compared to letting the nodes be in the tree but it wouldn't have the DOM Consistency problems if it parsed consistently regardless of the XMLness of the host doc
Hixie: I'm not actually advocating it as a solution, because it would be syntactically inconvenient to author
do you really think it's plausible to put the dom nodes in the dom inline and then change the zillions of things that need to be neutered? it seems really intractable to me
(i'm not a big fan of the attribute solution either)
(but i don't understand your objection to the inline thing)
Hixie: one possibility is that <template> is the wrong thing to want in the first place and we should instead focus on making it easy to write document fragments inline inside .js files
those seem like orthogonal concerns
Hixie: I do think it's tractable to make inline nodes as static as nodes in an XSLT program
but i'm definitely 100% behind solving the latter problem
i have no idea if nodes in an XSLT program are static
i wish we could just drop XSLT
Hixie: they aren't quite orthogonal to the extent <template> doesn't do anything in declaratively on its own
it's so ill-defined
(and used almost but not quite rarely enough to be dropped, grr)
Hixie: if <template> exists only to provide scripts a fragment to clone, the fragment might as well be put in the script
my understanding is that <template>'s main purpose is for web components, is that wrong?
Hixie: if that's the main purpose, I've missed some big-picture memo
i wasn't aware scripts would do much with them, i kinda assumed it would be mostly declarative like the repetition model
anyway i agree that html-in-script is something more interesting to solve
can you get anyone at mozilla to implement http://hixie.ch/specs/e4h/strawman ? :-)
Hixie: unlikely
Hixie: Conway's Law: it would belong to a different team

Hixie: anyway, my DOM Consistency concern would be less defensible if the proponents of <template>-as-a-wormhole-to-another-world were ready to introduce the same model to XML parsing and face the wrath of XML people
Hixie: if there are reasons not to do that with XML parsing, consider those same reasons raised as reasons not to do it in HTML parsing
(I'm behind in my W3C mailing list reading, so I'm not sure if the position on XML parsing has been reversed by now)
Hixie: that said, I'm uneasy about the wormhole model even if it applied to both XML and HTML
the reason not to do it with xml parsing is "the xml spec doesn't say to do it"
and... conway's law, we don't control the xml spec :-)
(i don't think they really care about xml)
(can't say i blame them)
well, XML is in the same department as XSLT: not a priority but can't be dropped
yeah
but doesn't have to be supported well either
rewriting Gecko's XML loading code paths is on my list of things to do
so XML is still planned to get engineering time
I even feel surprisingly motivated to do it
mozilla uses xml more than other browsers
Hixie: oh the Mozilla-special parts are not planned to get overhauled
loading xml has an impact on firefox load time
it doesn't have an impact on other browsers
it would be so much nicer not to have to worry about RDF and XUL
or XSLT
those are the 3 special cases
within the XML universe that is
hsivonen: i'm not sure why XML should be allowed to constrain the development of HTML
hsivonen: sounds more like the Gecko XML universe :)
if you want to use feature A that isn't supported in XML, then don't use XML.
abarth: well, at some point someone will use <template> in XML and then we'll be in a place where everyone loses if one browser vendor tries to be nice and support that case
wouldn't that be prevented by a test case?
and the note in the spec "Does not work in XML"
we have been in a situation where we had DOM inconsistency
the situation was bad
and we worked hard to get DOM Consistency
I always thought of that whole concept more as sharing the same DOM model
not as the same mapping-to-the-DOM model
annevk: well, they aren't going to share the same DOM model if one supports wormholes and one doesn't.
like using the same namespace, having the DOM behave the same in both environments (more or less)
hsivonen: one supports entity references and the other doesn't :)
abarth: different level of abstraction
hsivonen: I don't really see DOM consistency as a requirement that the effects the markup one of them can create in the DOM, the other has to too
anyway, there's no reason a DOM generated from XML can't support wormholes
hsivonen: e.g. XML can create namespaced nodes
isn't that just a property on the HTMLTempalteElement?
hsivonen: and now HTML would be able to create template trees
hsivonen: doesn't seem like a huge deal to me
abarth: no it's also how the contents are parsed and put on the fragment that attribute returns
put in*
annevk: I think making the DOM not be a syntax tree and turning it into an application-specific tree is a huge deal
is confused
doesn't shadow DOM do that?
I'm clearly missing something here
abarth: the idea is that <template>something</template> turns into <template/> in the DOM with an associated fragment that contains something
abarth: does the shadow DOM have a serialization?
I feel like you're conflating two things
1) there's a DOM, independent of serialization
that's shared between HTML and XML
2) there are HTML and XML serializations
<template> is not supported in the XML serilaization
that's it
abarth: but the DOM isn't just any tree. It's a tree designed to represent the syntax of tags-and-text markup
none of that has changed
well it kind of has
because the contents of <template> are elsewhere
not any more that changed it
abarth: so saying that the correspondence between tags-and-text and the DOM nodes is now different is a huge departure from what the DOM was designed to be
s/that/than/
so?
abarth: I think it's more; that's still in the DOM
having script in web page was a huge departure too
and it has turned out to be a good thing
well, don't put it in the DOM
put it in an HTMLTemplateElement propertly
like a shadow DOM
your argument has now shifted to not make reference to XML
which, IMHO, is a more interested conversation
s/interested/interesting/
can't type
abarth: no, XML is a useful aid for making my argument, because the correspondence between tags-and-text and DOM nodes is even more straight-forward in XML
the XML issue is off-point
it's more interesting to discuss whether this is a good or bad thing for HTML
irrespective of the existence of XML
for most intents and purposes, XML doesn't exist
it sounds like hsivonen's point is that you can serialize the DOM without element-specific knowledge, but that is already not true for HTML
hober: yt?

at the most basic, my argument is that 1) DOM isn't an app-specific API first; it's a direct representation of tags-and-text syntax. 2) That essential nature of the DOM shouldn't be changed lightly, because changing fundamentals has unforeseen consequences. 3) Stuff that has unforeseen consequences shouldn't be done in gung-ho "let's just implement this feature [in Chrome]" manner
1) is clearly false IMHO, since all the HTML elements have dedicated interfaces into the DOM
(3) seems prematurely argumentative
I'm not aware of that happening with <template>
in fact, it was first an application-specific API (new Image(), new Option(), etc) onto which a generic model was then layered
retroactively
so I'm not trying to argue what specific bad effects this might have, because my fear is that changing fundamentals will have consequences I don't see now
but you also don't see the potential good effects
and clearly nobody is doing 3) since if this was gung-ho, it'd be in the spec already instead of people trying to convince you :-)
annevk: true
Hixie: well, just brushing off XML to the side instead of having a design that integrates will all existing parts of the platform seems gung-ho to me
(it's so weird to be the person who seems to care the most about XML)
might be worth studying http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/desktop/ms766512(v=vs.85).aspx

(on an unrelated note: i think i'm going to put little "fingerprint" icons in the spec in the places that leak fingerprintable data. If anyone has an icon to contribute, or a list of places that should get the icon, please let me know, e.g. by filing a bug or sending me an e-mail.)
but I cannot find much information about success/failure

hsivonen: i'm all for solutions that work in XML too. I just haven't seen one. I don't think we should sacrifice the web's progress on the altar of XML -- if we can't find a solution, we have to move on, imho.
annevk: yeah, data islands are precedent. and failed precedent
Hixie: about #1, even though elements have convenience properties and methods, the tree structure corresponds to tags-and-text rather than application-specific considerations
it doesn't though
hsivonen: failed because unappealing or because lack of adoption by other vendors?
or rather it only does if you know some special rules for some of the tags
hsivonen: successful enough for https://developer.mozilla.org/en/Using_XML_Data_Islands_in_Mozilla it seems
annevk: unappealing to other vendors ;-)
hsivonen: the tree structure was not first
Hixie: the current crop of implementations is no longer based on the model that existed before the tree structure
hsivonen: the tree structure was layered on top of the app-specific API years later.
hsivonen: that doesn't seem relevant to the question of what it is
Hixie: rather, it was layered under
i'm not arguing that the tree structure isn't important, just that it's not some core concept that should be considered holy
the dom _is_ an application specific api, was from the start, and we haven't made it any less so (q.v. srcdoc="")
hsivonen: how would you feel if we allowed XL in <script> ?
XL?
it just so happens that the syntax of JavaScript doesn't look like tags-and-text
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/XL_(XML_programming_language)
but there isn't any reason why we shouldn't be able to use a scripting language
whose syntax is tags-and-text
then the <script> tag would do the same thing that's bothering you about the <template> tag
the HTML spec already caters to that possibility
abarth: xforms actions is the language i usually reference in this context
ok, there are lots of them
XL was the first one I found :)
CSS even _has_ a tree structure _in the DOM_
abarth: I think supporting that sort of language in <script> would be a can of worms
abarth: I'm aware that WHATWG HTML allowes (allowed?) it, but fortunately, no one really supports a languages like like
what if we replaced the < brackets with {
abarth: it would make it less of a can of worms from the DOM perspective
it's unclear to me why < has a special status in the syntax of scripting languages
abarth: because < is special in the wrapper
i mean, JavaScript uses <
abarth: but this is theoretical. I disapprove of non-JS <script> language in general, including Dart and VBScript
it just doesn't look like tags
IMHO, that's short sighted
abarth: < in inline JS is a Polyglotness problem
abarth: i think for this line of argumentation CSS is the better path, because it is already parsed into an exposed OM
yes, hence not supporting <template> in XML
so, not allowed in polyglot
ok, consider CSS
but using < rather than {
abarth: you are basically trying to argue that since we already have cans of worms, it's OK to open some more
my argument is that your argument from purity ignores that we're already impure
we don't just have a can of worms, dude. We're swimming in a swamp of worms.
Hixie: I had them in plural already :-)
the correspondence between DOM and tags-and-text isn't as tight as you make it sound
abarth: from impl point of view, <script> is the most special of elements
abarth: I accept it as legacy, but I don't view it as a role model for introducing anything else
i dunno about _that_
<script> is bad, granted.
DOCTYPE has got to be more special
but <table> parsing is crazy
<iframe> is buts
nuts even
<object> is a land of its own
<frameset>...
not to mention the magic that is nested <a> parsing!
ok i'll stop now
Hixie: none of those can do the kind of things to the parser state as <script>
<script> is only crazy because of document.write()
which by the way is why i neutered that for svg, which you keep arguing we should bring back! :-P
Hixie: on the XML side, it can suspend the parser as a nod to document.write even though document.write doesn't work
needs to go to sleep soon
i don't recall what we did in xml mode
i don't really care about xml
hsivonen: i don't see anything in the spec that does the document.write() thing in xml, am i missing something?
non-async/defer script block the xml parser to show a predictable DOM state to scripts
maybe it's not specced anywhere
<Script src=""> blocks the parser's modifications of the DOM, sure
that's got nothing to do with document.write()
nothing?
that's just the scripts being synchronously loaded
the same would occur if document.write() didn't exist at all
I don't believe it would
ok
either way
i did not have document.write() in mind when speccing that
and it has nothing to do with document.write() in the spec
it's just sync external script loading
and it's hardly "crazy"
compared to things like <object>'s processing model
object is very light in craziness from the parser impl POV
oh for parsing, sure
parsing in general is very light in craziness from the big picture point of view :-)
XML parsing
script has the worst parsing complications
in XML parsing, it has the only complications
well, i guess </video> and </object> technically have some minor complications
but that's about it, in xml
and <svg>
oh because of their event nonsense?
right
yeah i haven't been affected by that so it doesn't come to mind :-)

anyway. i think the original point stands: if there's a solution that works for XML, I'm sure people would be happy to hear about it, but so far none have been put forward, and it doesn't seem sensible to block progress on that. And when you forget about XML, it really doesn't seem like the proposal is unreasonable; it reuses existing logic.
ok, HD canvas is done, modulo all the bugs i just introduced that hober and zcorpan will point out
next up is removeHitRegion(), i guess
tomorrow
how do URLs in <template> descendant elements resolve?
I guess base URLs would have to work
we could just modify XML really
introduce <xml:template> or something odd like that
http://what-if.xkcd.com/3/ is awesome
Is there any circumstance where you do not have a base URL?
(other than the address bar)
<xml:foo> is never the right solution
for evidence, see xml:lang, xml:id and <xml:include>
hsivonen: yeah after I mentioned that I wondered whether I should correct it to html:template
hsivonen: or just let it be warnocked
http://www.w3.org/community/xmlhypermedia/ created
by the xml:href guy
interesting list of technologies on this "Anatomy of a Web Developer" T-shirt http://rlv.zcache.com/anatomy_of_a_web_developer_brain_driven_by_mysql_tshirt-p235273746211126463b7wq7_400.jpg
didn't know there was *the* xml:href guy
so not only have I semi-accidentally come into contact with browsing context code, I have even more accidentally came into contact with B/F cache code :-( :-(
let's see if Hixie has conceptualized the B/F cache better than the Gecko code that introduced it...
I wonder if Gecko ever puts non-"complete" docs in the B/F cache in the first place...
smaug____: do you happen to know?
it shouldn't
smaug____: ok. thanks
hsivonen: btw it would be nice to try to fix the the parser bug that causes double-quoted charset parameter values to be reported as errors in the validator
I can't remember where the source of that is but I vaguely recall being in the chardet code maybe
MikeSmith: does the spec not treat those as errors?
no, not as far as I know
interesting
I don't know that the HTML spec says anything about the syntax for the header case
anyway, the mime-type RFCs allow it
oh this is about header parsing rather than processing the value after header parsing?
though only for double quotes, not for single once
yeah
one common place where it gets reported is for the built-in Web server that ships with mercurial
hgweb
ok
hsivonen: related mercurial bug I filed: http://bz.selenic.com/show_bug.cgi?id=3531
Ms2ger: Problem is ofc that they're really so damn verbose. Should be a way to say "I want to see the important stuff". So then it's possible to fix that first...
Ms2ger: (the idlharness that is)
Well, all of idlharness is obscure edge cases, really :)
Nope, checking that properties exist, is readonly, returning expected objects back that behave as described. That stuff is useful for doing a quick skeleton of code to further refine and build on. :]
Well, depends on obsucrity level ofc, but not that obscure :P
Easy; you just import the IDL file and let the bindings code do its wo... Oh
curses Gecko's manual bindings
Hmm? Thought Gecko had a binding system?
About 5
And the hand-written parts don't look nice...
why does http://trac.webkit.org/browser/trunk/Source/WebCore/platform/KURL.cpp#L74 not list ports for ws: and wss:?
they're the same as for http?
indeed they are
hsivonen: so I find the cause of the parser not handling double-quotes in the Content-Type header charset parameter is not in chardet but in the validator util code
https://bitbucket.org/validator/util/src/de960161c5f1/src/nu/validator/xml/ContentTypeParser.java#cl-37
private static final Pattern CHARSET = Pattern.compile("^\\s*charset\\s*=\\s*(\\S+)\\s*$");
should be:
private static final Pattern CHARSET = Pattern.compile("^\\s*charset\\s*=\\s*\"(\\S+)\"\\s*$");
instead I guess
hmm are the spaces allowed there?
goes back to read whatever RFC it is
Yes, they are.
heh, nothing is quite as horrid as double-escaped regexes in languages without a regex syntax
perl comes close
it always does
gsnedders: oh yeah?
who was it that objected to just "img.src = blob", again? was it just MS?
(because they seemed to object to anything that wasn't their own broken oneTimeOnly thing)
I think that img.src = non-string is silly
from productions in RFC 2616 at least I can't see that the spaces are allowed
gsnedders:
I guess I must be missing something
zewt: it was sicking
zewt: primarily because of the CSS thing, which I don't think people will use
i'm personally on the fence (for whatever that's worth, not being a sicking myself)
having to add new entry points for every single api seems a lot bigger than changing the existing ones
but it is nicer
one thing that makes me nervous about it is that it makes it "optional" for APIs
some apis will inevitably go "why would you want to do that?" and not add the entry point, instead of it being a universal feature
that just requires a bit of hammering
but we can go with what we have now
hsivonen: and would be better to be using a real parser there instead of regexp :) I'll file a TODO bug for it
annevk: well, modulo https://www.w3.org/Bugs/Public/show_bug.cgi?id=16790#c13
calling a black-box script that does a document.write("<script...") and having blob URLs in the caller be revoked would be bad
good morning, Whatwg!
morning, dglazkov
MikeSmith: Implicit white space is what you're missing.
jwalden: So, we now outnumber these accessor property people. Mwhaha! :)
I landed the __proto__ patch about an hour ago, we'll see how it goes
hmm authority is annoying to parse
[bits[:bits]@]bits[:bits] is the grammar or some such
but then wildly more complicated
Hmm, I got a "DMCA Removal Notice - Link Removal Request" about "an unauthorised link to our clients web site" on http://philip.html5.org/data/doctypes.html
annevk: Since you're hosting it and would presumably have to deal with any problems if they're serious: Should I care?
Philip`: it's it a felony to send bogus DMCA requests or something? heh
zewt: I guess that only applies to actual take-down notices, not to emails which happen to mention "DMCA" in their subject line
"something something DMCA - do whatever I tell you to"
Philip`: DMCA Removal Notice - buy me a pizza
This one says "If the links are not removed as soon as possible then we may have to take further action such as requesting a DMCA take-down notice or reporting the links to Google"
(I'd have thought Google was already aware of all my links, since that's what their business is based on...)
"you're going to tell a search engine about my webpage? please do!"
Oh, look
First action as a CSSOM editor: "Hey, do you *really* want me to *define* things?"
gsnedders: I don't think I'm missing implicit white space as far the the RFCs go
there's nothing implicit about it in RFC 2616
rather it's just simply not allowed
if browser engines allow it, then that should be specified somewhere
Ms2ger: oh, something is fixed?
Dunno
Philip`: sounds like you can just ignore it
Philip`: just ignore.
hober: your quick review of the HD stuff would be nice, to make sure i'm not barking up the wrong tree
MikeSmith: ping
am I reading it correctly that IRIs don't allow non-BMP characters?
http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3987#page-8
oh well, not that it matters what that spec says
an established tradition with rfcs
for URL parsing it's actually easier if the internal URL object stores path segments and the filename
so when you resolve "../" against something else, you just copy the path segments from the base URL (along with everything else, but not the filename and such) and just pop the topmost one
(after you tokenize "../" per path tokenization rules of course)
(and only if these are hierarchical schemes)
and then .pathname is just the concat of path segments with / followed by / followed by filename
Philip`: There's no such thing as an unauthorized link.  You can ignore that.
annevk: what is the filename?
karlcow: remainder except for query/fragment
http://example.org/path/foo/morefoo?blah
morefoo
path segments would be an array of path and foo
In which context it is a filename?
query would be blah
it's just a term
scratches his head
yeah, the URL related terms are not too great
but we are kind of stuck with them given the API
the path is "/path/foo/morefoo"
though I'm somewhat hesitant to call fragment hash instead
and query search...
it's often tempting in writing these specs to just call everything "opaque term #391" and so forth
But then you need a registry...
just to shortcircuit the confusion and bikeshed bickering that inevitably results
Tabatkins: "html spec opaque term #391"
Ah, distributed extensibility.
Hixie: shortcircuit the confusion with terms like that? interesting universe
yeah the problem is it introduces a whole different confusion
where everyone has no idea what anything means
but seriously, people sometimes get so hung up on the terms and ignore their definitions, it drives me crazy
uhuh
e.g. the "cookie-free document" thing recently, which was very clearly defined as meaning "document that cannot get cookies", not "document that has no cookies"
yet people wrote code assuming it meant the latter!
(i changed that to "cookie-averse documents")
omg
and the definition was like two sentences from where the offending requirement was
I... want to refuse to believe that people would write code based solely on the name of a feature, rather than reading any of the actual spec.
i wish
anyway, that kind of thing is what makes me want to use really opaque terms so that there's no way to implement it without truly understanding it
obviously a non-starter in practice
ok, i've added removeHitRegion() for microsoft
that's apple and microsoft dealt with
opera wants data: in web works, mozilla wants... what was it, someone had a suggestion earlier
inputmode, i think
that's gonna require research
now wonders what are the APIs in different std libs for programming languages.
* for URIs
ok... data: workers done
that leaves autocompletetype for chrome and inputmode for mozilla
Hixie: how did you handle same-origin that redirects to a data: URL?
really really odd, pages for mobile browsers seem to use event.srcElement reasonable often
I wonder why
srcElement is IEism
not webkitism
annevk: bummer. redirects.
reopens the editor
I thought it was an easy fix for XHR too and then decided to pun on it when I realized redirects
annevk: oh it's already dealt with. As soon as you have a redirect to a different origin, the fetch aborts.
annevk: the way i specced it, it's only data: URLs given in the actual argument that are special-cases
special-cased
I guess that's okay
the redirect case is kind of weird

If you're an implementor and object to the changes described in http://www.w3.org/wiki/User:Mtanalin/legend-placement#Details it would be nice if you said so in the wbs poll on the matter before friday: https://www.w3.org/2002/09/wbs/40318/issue-200-objection-poll/
Oh jesus.
Tabatkins: exactly.
adding some screenshots to http://wiki.whatwg.org/wiki/Text_input_keyboard_mode_control
hober: why does it matter? surely if the wg just makes the spec say something dumb, it'll just be ignored
Hixie: all things being equal, it'd be nice if the wg took its charter requirement to actively pursue convergence.
s/took/took seriously/
hober: that's up to the chairs
hober: and the editors
indeed, and they base their decisions on, among other things, the wbs survey results. having voices of reason in the survey results helps improve the outcome
hober: if they took their charter requirement to actively pursue convergence seriously, they wouldn't base their decisions on surveys
scrolls up
nicely written objection TabAtkins
I'm not sure I could really add anything substantial to that
my big objection is that there is insufficient benefit shown to offset the cost of adding a new <ilegend> element - in fact, quite the opposite, it looks like language pollution.
tantek: Simply adding that Mozilla objects for the same reason would be useful.

however, that's not really a new objection compared to what you wrote, so I'm not going to bother adding a "me too" answer since the chairs say they don't look at # of votes etc. but rather just the strength of arguments.
While votes themselves aren't counted, weight of impl opinion is.
it shouldn't be an (un)popularity contest
It should absolutely include popularity among implementors.
Given that they're the ones implementing the features. ^_^
it shouldn't be a contest at all
I'd rather see the chairs make a good rational decision based on your objection alone. I think that will show that strength of argument matters more than specific parties objecting.
plus I would rather prefer having an element called <iamlegend> or even better <thelastmanonearth>
the objections have long been discussed, if the chairs wanted to make rational decisions they could have done so months ago (when i did)
Past experience suggests the chairs don't make good rational decisions on these things.
(not to mention that in this case the problems are self-evident)
Tabatkins - my experience has been contrary - e.g. decisions on Issue 183, Issue 184. Have been quite rational.
gave up hope on the chairs when they decided on a proposal that was literally self-contradictory
I'm willing to believe they're not consistently irrational. ^_^
Hixie, baby/bathwater. No one is perfect.
this isn't about lacking perfection
Anyway, I think the chairs will also be increasingly biased *against* new elements in an effort to get closure on the HTML5 feature set.

it was clear in their decision that they didn't even know what they were deciding on -- the thing they pointed to had two different proposals, both internally inconsistent, and they hadn't even noticed
and they continued to insist for something like 6 months, even after every single problem was discussed to death, that their decision was right
Hixie, not everyone is as good at spotting deep internal inconsistencies as you are :P
this isn't "deep internal inconsistencies"
this proposal wasn't even consistent at a shallow level
isn't even sure which issue/proposal(s) we're talking about, but suspects it has something to do with accessibility.
some canvas thing last year
quick question for those of you that went to TPAC2012 and are considering going to TPAC2013:
... isn't TPAC2012 in October?
Very end of Oct/beginning of Nov.
make that went to TPAC2011 and are considering going to TPAC2012 :)
Oh, got it.
missed the implication of the question. ^_^

Did you get value out of the TPAC2011 pre-scheduled morning sessions (before the BarCamp-style sessions), or not? (e.g. lots, some value, none, negative, walked out) And if you did get value, any suggestions for "global" topics for TPAC2012?
(that's the question, before was just setup)
(totally unscientific poll)
I don't remember what they were, so... apparently not.
I think fantasai and I skipped them to work on the slides for out later session.
do you mean on the tech plenary day?
othermaciej yes
Tabatkins I'
I'll take that as "none" for you and fantasai then

got no value what so ever as the WGs he's part of didn't go to TPAC last year, and are going this year but now the TPAC is in Europe and can't get funding and there is no remote on the TPAC site this year :( I am a sad panda
More of an "abstain", but close enough to be "none".
gavinc: I'll take you in my baggage.
more of a "decided to not go" than "abstain" which if anything is a vote against based on pre-evaluation.
uh, almost forgot tpac... more traveling this year
IIRC the unconference part of the day was worthwhile
but I don't remember the non-unconference part.
tantek: Yeah, but we had things to do, and also the weather was *gorgeous* outside.
i got a lot of OpenTTD done that week
hober - I'll take "don't remember" as a "none"

other than that, pretty much every meeting i was in that i thought was productive (not many to start with) ended up being a no-op because the decisions made there were reversed or abandoned within a month or two
so i'd have to go with "negative"
Hixie: He's not polling about WG meetings.
i didn't go to any wg meetings
